cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
when did the eagles win the super bowl
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process:
To determine when the Philadelphia Eagles won the Super Bowl, I need to recall the history of the Super Bowl and the specific seasons in which the Eagles participated. The Eagles reached the Super Bowl multiple times, but they won their first and only championship in the 2017 season. The game they won was Super Bowl LII, which took place on February 4, 2018. They defeated the New England Patriots in that game.

Answer:
The Philadelphia Eagles won the Super Bowl on February 4, 2018.

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
when did the eagles win the super bowl
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['The Eagles defeated the New England Patriots by a score of 41–33 in Super Bowl LII at U.S. Bank Stadium in Minneapolis, Minnesota on February 4, 2018, ending the alleged curse.\n', "The Eagles went on to win Super Bowl LII, 41–33. It was the team's first NFL championship since 1960, and first ever Super Bowl win.\n", "On January 23, 2005, the Eagles reached a fourth consecutive conference championship game (the first time this happened in the salary cap era of the NFL). At long last, the Eagles justified the hopes of their long-suffering fan base, defeating Michael Vick's much-hyped Atlanta Falcons, 27-10, sending them to their first Super Bowl in 24 years. The victory sent the city of Philadelphia into wild celebrations.\n", 'On February 4, 2018, the Philadelphia Eagles defeated the New England Patriots in Super Bowl LII 41-33 to win their first Super Bowl in team history, and first championship since the 1960 NFL Championship.\n', 'The Eagles have won four league titles. Three of these were won prior to the start of the Super Bowl era (in 1948, 1949, and 1960). The fourth and most recent championship was won in Super Bowl LII.\n', "This alleged curse supposedly prevented the Philadelphia Eagles franchise from winning a Super Bowl game. The origin of this curse dates back to 1960, when the Eagles defeated Vince Lombardi and the Green Bay Packers in the 1960 NFL Championship Game. This would be the only playoff loss in Lombardi's coaching career. Following Lombardi's death in 1970, the league honored his legacy by naming the Super Bowl trophy after him. This renaming, combined with the Eagles inability to win another championship after their 1960 victory, led some Eagles fans to believe the franchise was cursed by Vince Lombardi; that beating Lombardi meant never winning the trophy named after him. During that time, the Eagles accumulated a lot of playoff heartbreak, including 2 Super Bowl losses to the Oakland Raiders and New England Patriots, and 3 consecutive NFC Championship Game losses from 2001-2003. \n", 'On January 11, 2009, the team defeated the defending Super Bowl champion New York Giants 23–11 en route to their sixth NFC Championship Game. In the NFC Championship, the Eagles made a rally, going from down 24–6 at halftime to up 25–24 with three minutes left in the fourth quarter, but they lost to the Arizona Cardinals by a score of 32–25 after quarterback Kurt Warner scored a last minute touchdown.\n', 'BULLET::::- February 4 – The Philadelphia Eagles win their first Super Bowl in franchise history by defeating the New England Patriots, 41-33, in Super Bowl LII, ending a 57-year championship drought.\n', "The Philadelphia Eagles season was the franchise's 49th season in the National Football League, they made the postseason for the fourth straight season (first time in franchise history the Eagles had made the postseason four straight times). The team was coming off a Super Bowl loss to the Oakland Raiders the previous season. Because they made the Super Bowl in 1980, they were picked by many to not only reach the Super Bowl, but to win it as well. The Eagles began the 1981 season with 6 straight wins, their best ever start to a season at the time. The Eagles would win then 3 of their next 5 games to sit at 9-2. They would then lose their next 4 games to slip to 9-6 and were in danger of missing out on the playoffs. The next week, they hammered the Cardinals 38-0 to clinch a playoff berth for the fourth straight season. In the playoffs, they met their arch rivals the Giants. It was New York's first playoff appearance in 18 years. In the game, the Giants would stun the eagles 27-21, ending the Eagles season as well as hopes for a second straight Super Bowl appearance. The Eagles would not make the playoffs again until 1988. They also wouldn't reach the Super Bowl again until 2004.\n", 'The Eagles defeated the New England Patriots by a score of 41–33 in Super Bowl LII for their first Super Bowl victory in franchise history. It was also their fourth NFL Championship, and their first league title since 1960. This was the second time the Eagles and Patriots battled in a Super Bowl; when they met in Super Bowl XXXIX, the Patriots won 24–21. Backup quarterback Nick Foles was named Super Bowl MVP and became the first backup to receive this award since his opponent, Tom Brady, did so in Super Bowl XXXVI 15 years earlier. The Eagles defeated both Super Bowl teams from the previous NFL season (the New England Patriots and the Atlanta Falcons) in the playoffs, the third team to beat both of them this season, after the Carolina Panthers and Miami Dolphins. They also defeated both teams who had beaten them in their only two previous Super Bowl appearances: the Oakland Raiders in the regular season, who beat them in Super Bowl XV, and the Patriots in the Super Bowl, who previously beat them in Super Bowl XXXIX.\n']

Task Description:
Please extract content that may be unfamiliar to the model from these passages, 
which can provide the model with relevant background and unknown knowledge and concepts, 
helping it better understand the question. and analyze the role of these contents.

To answer the question "When did the Eagles win the Super Bowl?" we can extract and analyze several key pieces of information from the provided passages. The relevant content includes:

1. **Date and Event**: The Eagles won the Super Bowl on **February 4, 2018**, defeating the New England Patriots with a score of **41–33** in **Super Bowl LII**. This is crucial as it directly answers the question regarding the date of the Eagles' Super Bowl victory.

2. **Historical Context**: The victory marked the Eagles' **first Super Bowl win** in franchise history and their first NFL championship since **1960**. This context is important as it highlights the significance of the win for the team and its fans, emphasizing the long wait and the emotional weight of the victory.

3. **Curse Narrative**: The passages mention an "alleged curse" that supposedly prevented the Eagles from winning a Super Bowl since their last championship in 1960. This narrative adds depth to the understanding of the team's history and the emotional stakes involved for the fan base, which had endured years of playoff disappointments.

4. **Previous Super Bowl Appearances**: The Eagles had previously lost two Super Bowls, including one to the New England Patriots in **Super Bowl XXXIX**. This information provides context about the team's past struggles and the significance of finally winning the championship.

5. **Super Bowl MVP**: The backup quarterback **Nick Foles** was named Super Bowl MVP, which is noteworthy as it highlights an unexpected hero in the game and adds to the narrative of the Eagles' victory being a significant underdog story.

6. **Franchise History**: The Eagles' victory in Super Bowl LII was their **fourth NFL Championship** overall, with three of those titles won before the Super Bowl era. This historical perspective helps to frame the achievement within the broader context of the team's legacy.

### Role of Extracted Content:

- **Temporal Context**: The date of the victory is essential for answering the question directly.
- **Emotional and Cultural Significance**: The background about the curse and the long wait for a championship helps to convey the emotional weight of the victory for fans and the franchise.
- **Historical Perspective**: Understanding the Eagles' previous Super Bowl losses and their overall championship history provides a richer narrative, illustrating the significance of their win in 2018.
- **Characterization of Key Players**: Mentioning Nick Foles as MVP adds a personal touch to the story, highlighting individual achievement within the team success.

In summary, the extracted content not only answers the question but also enriches the understanding of the Eagles' Super Bowl win by providing historical, emotional, and cultural context. This helps to paint a fuller picture of the significance of the event in the franchise's history.

The passages provided contain a wealth of information regarding the Philadelphia Eagles' history, particularly focusing on their Super Bowl victories and the context surrounding them. Here’s a consolidated summary and analysis of the key points:

### Summary of Key Information:

1. **Super Bowl LII Victory**:
   - The Philadelphia Eagles won their first Super Bowl (Super Bowl LII) on February 4, 2018, defeating the New England Patriots with a score of 41-33.
   - This victory marked the end of a 57-year championship drought for the Eagles, as their last NFL championship prior to this was in 1960.

2. **Historical Context**:
   - The Eagles had previously reached the Super Bowl in 1980 and 2004 but lost both times (to the Oakland Raiders and the New England Patriots, respectively).
   - The 2018 victory was significant not only for the franchise but also for the city of Philadelphia, which celebrated the long-awaited championship.

3. **Cultural Significance**:
   - The Eagles' inability to secure a Super Bowl win for decades led to the emergence of a "curse" narrative among fans, stemming from their 1960 championship win against Vince Lombardi's Green Bay Packers. This narrative was fueled by the team's playoff heartbreaks in subsequent years.

4. **Notable Players and Achievements**:
   - Nick Foles, the Eagles' backup quarterback, was named Super Bowl MVP, becoming the first backup to win this award since Tom Brady in Super Bowl XXXVI.
   - The Eagles' victory was notable for being their first Super Bowl win in franchise history, which added to the emotional weight of the game for fans and players alike.

- **Comprehension and Expansion**: By synthesizing this information, one can appreciate not just the facts of the Eagles' Super Bowl win but also the broader implications for the team and its fans. ### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

To determine when the Philadelphia Eagles won the Super Bowl, I will analyze the historical context of the team’s Super Bowl appearances and victories, as well as the significance of their win in relation to the franchise and its fans.

1. **Historical Context**: The Eagles have a long history in the NFL, with their first NFL championship occurring in 1960. However, they did not win a Super Bowl until 2018. They reached the Super Bowl in 1980 and 2004 but lost both times, which contributed to a narrative of frustration and disappointment among fans.

2. **Super Bowl LII Victory**: The Eagles won their first Super Bowl (Super Bowl LII) on February 4, 2018, defeating the New England Patriots 41-33. This victory was particularly significant as it ended a 57-year championship drought for the franchise. The emotional weight of this win was felt deeply in Philadelphia, where fans celebrated a long-awaited triumph.

3. **Cultural Significance**: The Eagles' history of playoff heartbreaks and their previous Super Bowl losses contributed to a "curse" narrative among fans, which was rooted in their inability to win after their 1960 championship. This narrative was a source of both humor and frustration for the fan base, making the 2018 victory even more poignant.

4. **Notable Players and Achievements**: Nick Foles, the Eagles' backup quarterback, played a crucial role in the victory and was named Super Bowl MVP. His performance was historic, as he became the first backup quarterback to win this award since Tom Brady in 2002. This highlights the theme of resilience and unexpected success that characterized the Eagles' Super Bowl run.

5. **Broader Implications**: The Eagles' victory not only marked a significant achievement for the team but also served as a unifying moment for the city of Philadelphia. It represented a culmination of decades of hope and struggle, transforming the team's identity and solidifying its place in NFL history.

By synthesizing this information, I can appreciate the significance of the Eagles' Super Bowl win beyond just the date and score. It reflects a narrative of perseverance, community pride, and the emotional journey of a franchise and its fans.

### Answer:
The Philadelphia Eagles won the Super Bowl on February 4, 2018, by defeating the New England Patriots 41-33 in Super Bowl LII. This victory marked the team's first Super Bowl win in franchise history and ended a 57-year championship drought, making it a momentous occasion for the team and its fans.

Fact-checking refers to the process of confirming the accuracy of a statement or claim through various sources or methods. 
This process aims to ensure that statements or claims are based on reliable and verifiable information while eliminating inaccurate or misleading content. 
Fact-checking may involve the examination of data, literature, expert opinions, or other trustworthy sources.
In the context of artificial intelligence, model illusion refers to the overconfidence response of the AI. 
When a model exhibits an 'illusion' (a tendency to output deceptive data), it indicates that the training data used by the model does not necessarily support the rationality of its outputs.

Three of these were won prior to the start of the Super Bowl era (in 1948, 1949, and 1960). The fourth and most recent championship was won in Super Bowl LII.\n', "This alleged curse supposedly prevented the Philadelphia Eagles franchise from winning a Super Bowl game. The origin of this curse dates back to 1960, when the Eagles defeated Vince Lombardi and the Green Bay Packers in the 1960 NFL Championship Game. This would be the only playoff loss in Lombardi's coaching career. Following Lombardi's death in 1970, the league honored his legacy by naming the Super Bowl trophy after him. This renaming, combined with the Eagles inability to win another championship after their 1960 victory, led some Eagles fans to believe the franchise was cursed by Vince Lombardi; that beating Lombardi meant never winning the trophy named after him. During that time, the Eagles accumulated a lot of playoff heartbreak, including 2 Super Bowl losses to the Oakland Raiders and New England Patriots, and 3 consecutive NFC Championship Game losses from 2001-2003. \n", 'On January 11, 2009, the team defeated the defending Super Bowl champion New York Giants 23–11 en route to their sixth NFC Championship Game. In the NFC Championship, the Eagles made a rally, going from down 24–6 at halftime to up 25–24 with three minutes left in the fourth quarter, but they lost to the Arizona Cardinals by a score of 32–25 after quarterback Kurt Warner scored a last minute touchdown.\n', 'BULLET::::- February 4 – The Philadelphia Eagles win their first Super Bowl in franchise history by defeating the New England Patriots, 41-33, in Super Bowl LII, ending a 57-year championship drought.\n', "The Philadelphia Eagles season was the franchise's 49th season in the National Football League, they made the postseason for the fourth straight season (first time in franchise history the Eagles had made the postseason four straight times). The team was coming off a Super Bowl loss to the Oakland Raiders the previous season. Because they made the Super Bowl in 1980, they were picked by many to not only reach the Super Bowl, but to win it as well. The Eagles began the 1981 season with 6 straight wins, their best ever start to a season at the time. The Eagles would win then 3 of their next 5 games to sit at 9-2. They would then lose their next 4 games to slip to 9-6 and were in danger of missing out on the playoffs. The next week, they hammered the Cardinals 38-0 to clinch a playoff berth for the fourth straight season. In the playoffs, they met their arch rivals the Giants. It was New York's first playoff appearance in 18 years. In the game, the Giants would stun the eagles 27-21, ending the Eagles season as well as hopes for a second straight Super Bowl appearance. The Eagles would not make the playoffs again until 1988. They also wouldn't reach the Super Bowl again until 2004.\n", 'The Eagles defeated the New England Patriots by a score of 41–33 in Super Bowl LII for their first Super Bowl victory in franchise history. Backup quarterback Nick Foles was named Super Bowl MVP and became the first backup to receive this award since his opponent, Tom Brady, did so in Super Bowl XXXVI 15 years earlier. The Eagles defeated both Super Bowl teams from the previous NFL season (the New England Patriots and the Atlanta Falcons) in the playoffs, the third team to beat both of them this season, after the Carolina Panthers and Miami Dolphins. They also defeated both teams who had beaten them in their only two previous Super Bowl appearances: the Oakland Raiders in the regular season, who beat them in Super Bowl XV, and the Patriots in the Super Bowl, who previously beat them in Super Bowl XXXIX.\n']

question_info.question: when did the eagles win the super bowl
passages:
The Eagles defeated the New England Patriots by a score of 41–33 in Super Bowl LII at U.S. Bank Stadium in Minneapolis, Minnesota on February 4, 2018, ending the alleged curse.
The Eagles went on to win Super Bowl LII, 41–33. It was the team's first NFL championship since 1960, and first ever Super Bowl win.
On January 23, 2005, the Eagles reached a fourth consecutive conference championship game (the first time this happened in the salary cap era of the NFL). At long last, the Eagles justified the hopes of their long-suffering fan base, defeating Michael Vick's much-hyped Atlanta Falcons, 27-10, sending them to their first Super Bowl in 24 years. The victory sent the city of Philadelphia into wild celebrations.
On February 4, 2018, the Philadelphia Eagles defeated the New England Patriots in Super Bowl LII 41-33 to win their first Super Bowl in team history, and first championship since the 1960 NFL Championship.
The Eagles have won four league titles. Three of these were won prior to the start of the Super Bowl era (in 1948, 1949, and 1960). The fourth and most recent championship was won in Super Bowl LII.
This alleged curse supposedly prevented the Philadelphia Eagles franchise from winning a Super Bowl game. The origin of this curse dates back to 1960, when the Eagles defeated Vince Lombardi and the Green Bay Packers in the 1960 NFL Championship Game. This would be the only playoff loss in Lombardi's coaching career. Following Lombardi's death in 1970, the league honored his legacy by naming the Super Bowl trophy after him. This renaming, combined with the Eagles inability to win another championship after their 1960 victory, led some Eagles fans to believe the franchise was cursed by Vince Lombardi; that beating Lombardi meant never winning the trophy named after him. During that time, the Eagles accumulated a lot of playoff heartbreak, including 2 Super Bowl losses to the Oakland Raiders and New England Patriots, and 3 consecutive NFC Championship Game losses from 2001-2003. 
On January 11, 2009, the team defeated the defending Super Bowl champion New York Giants 23–11 en route to their sixth NFC Championship Game. In the NFC Championship, the Eagles made a rally, going from down 24–6 at halftime to up 25–24 with three minutes left in the fourth quarter, but they lost to the Arizona Cardinals by a score of 32–25 after quarterback Kurt Warner scored a last minute touchdown.
BULLET::::- February 4 – The Philadelphia Eagles win their first Super Bowl in franchise history by defeating the New England Patriots, 41-33, in Super Bowl LII, ending a 57-year championship drought.
The Philadelphia Eagles season was the franchise's 49th season in the National Football League, they made the postseason for the fourth straight season (first time in franchise history the Eagles had made the postseason four straight times). The team was coming off a Super Bowl loss to the Oakland Raiders the previous season. Because they made the Super Bowl in 1980, they were picked by many to not only reach the Super Bowl, but to win it as well. The Eagles began the 1981 season with 6 straight wins, their best ever start to a season at the time. The Eagles would win then 3 of their next 5 games to sit at 9-2. They would then lose their next 4 games to slip to 9-6 and were in danger of missing out on the playoffs. The next week, they hammered the Cardinals 38-0 to clinch a playoff berth for the fourth straight season. In the playoffs, they met their arch rivals the Giants. It was New York's first playoff appearance in 18 years. In the game, the Giants would stun the eagles 27-21, ending the Eagles season as well as hopes for a second straight Super Bowl appearance. The Eagles would not make the playoffs again until 1988. They also wouldn't reach the Super Bowl again until 2004.
The Eagles defeated the New England Patriots by a score of 41–33 in Super Bowl LII for their first Super Bowl victory in franchise history. It was also their fourth NFL Championship, and their first league title since 1960. This was the second time the Eagles and Patriots battled in a Super Bowl; when they met in Super Bowl XXXIX, the Patriots won 24–21. Backup quarterback Nick Foles was named Super Bowl MVP and became the first backup to receive this award since his opponent, Tom Brady, did so in Super Bowl XXXVI 15 years earlier. The Eagles defeated both Super Bowl teams from the previous NFL season (the New England Patriots and the Atlanta Falcons) in the playoffs, the third team to beat both of them this season, after the Carolina Panthers and Miami Dolphins. They also defeated both teams who had beaten them in their only two previous Super Bowl appearances: the Oakland Raiders in the regular season, who beat them in Super Bowl XV, and the Patriots in the Super Bowl, who previously beat them in Super Bowl XXXIX.
